stimulusHtml:
Read each part carefully. Show all your work for each part of the question. The parts within the question may not have equal weight.

Students are going to perform an experiment to determine the mass m of an object using the setup shown above. They are expected to find m by plotting their data in a graph. The students have access to equipment commonly found in a high school physics laboratory, but the experiment must use the setup as shown above, which includes an object of unknown mass m, which sits on a surface where friction is negligible. The object is pressed against a linear spring with known spring constant k, and the spring is compressed a distance x from the springâ€™s equilibrium position. The object is released, and it slides across the table and lands on the floor.

(a) Briefly identify each quantity to be measured, the symbol used to represent that quantity, and the equipment that would be used to measure the quantity.

(b) Briefly describe the procedure to be used to determine the mass m of the object. Provide enough detail so that another student could replicated the experiment, including any steps necessary to reduce experimental uncertainty. As needed, use the symbols defined in part (a) above.
(c) Which quantities (raw data or calculated from the data) would be graphed on the vertical and horizontal axes to produce a graph that could be used to determine the mass m of the object?
(d) Describe which information from the graph described in part (c) would be used and how that information would be used to determine the mass m of the object.

(e) In another experiment, the object is pushed against the spring and released. When it reaches the edge of the table, the object collides with and pushes a long uniform rod pivoted around its top end. The collision causes the rod to rotate around its pivot, and the object is then projected off the table, as shown. Which of the following quantities of the object-rod system, if any, are constant during the collision?

  • Kinetic energy
  • Angular momentum around the pivot
  • Angular momentum around the pivot
